Award.AwardTitle: Contextual Research-Large Empirical: Race and Gender in Context: A Multi-method of Study of Risk and Resilience in African American College Students' Pathways in STEM Areas

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project addresses a persistent STEM problem: recruiting and retaining African American students. The outcomes should expand knowledge and understanding of factors that are deterrents to African American students entering STEM disciplines by examining the academic progress of college students at four different universities (University of Michigan, Michigan State, Wayne State and Western Michigan). The study will include students in both STEM and non-STEM majors to study processes unique to students from differing academic contexts. The Principal Investigators will collaborate with the NSF funded Michigan-Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (MI-LSAMP), a multi-university initiative dedicated to promoting persistence in STEM areas among underrepresented minority college students.

The longitudinal, multi-method design focuses on within group variation in the impact of personal characteristics and contextual stigma on African American student STEM success, which is an unexplored area of research. Multiple theoretical models of relationships among racial stigma, gender, racial, academic and other identities and academic adjustment and performance will be tested. Major research questions include: What types of stigma do students experience around their racial and gender group memberships? Does academic identity mediate the relation between racial stigma experiences and academic adjustment? Are there direct effects of racial identity and/or gender identity on academic identity, daily/situational motivation, and overall academic adjustment?

The research includes four inter-related studies using different methods integrated into a single research project. They include a longitudinal survey, a diary study, in-depth semi-structured interviews, and an ethnographic assessment of the institutions. Although the studies are designed to answer independent questions, combining the studies affords a unique opportunity to answer a number of questions regarding the processes by which African American students succeed and others fail in STEM fields in a manner that would not be possible without such a multi-method design.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was a multi-method examination of African American college students and their experiences - their transitions to predominantly White universities and adjustment during their college years as they deal with demands and opportunities related to their academic contexts and challenges related to their racial and gender group memberships. A primary goal was to explore factors related to students’ academic risk and resilience in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) fields. The project involved a collaboration with the Michigan-Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (MI-LSAMP), an NSF-funded, multi-university initiative dedicated to promoting persistence in STEM areas among underrepresented minority college students. The collaboration allowed for examination of students from LSAMP’s ?ve partner universities in Michigan. A key project goal was to complement the work of MI-LSAMP by providing critical insights into factors that promote persistence or lead to attrition among underrepresented minority students in STEM areas.

Through surveys, daily diaries, and qualitative interviews, the project documented African American college students’ interpersonal and contextual experiences of stigma on their campuses (e.g., race and gender discrimination, negative classroom and campus climate) and the impacts of these contextual experiences over time. Findings demonstrated the deleterious impacts of race and gender stigma experiences on students’ academic identities (e.g., how they engage intellectually with their academic subjects and major disciplines, their feelings of belonging and motivation, and academic behaviors such as help-seeking, curricular efforts, and co-curricular activities). African American women were especially underrepresented in STEM but were also particularly likely to highlight experiences of discrimination and marginalization related to both their race and gender identities (for instance, experiencing treatment based in stereotypes of Black women) across both STEM and non-STEM contexts. Project results also highlighted how students draw on campus resources and assets (formal and informal mentors, peer communities) and their racial, cultural, and gender identities to strengthen or maintain their academic identity, and to mitigate the negative motivational and performance impacts of contextual stigma experiences.

The research project and its initial ?ndings contribute to understanding within-group variation in risk and resilience processes among African American college students pursuing STEM majors and careers, which has received relatively little systematic attention. Despite the growing concern about African American students’ underrepresentation in and lower persistence in STEM ?elds, a disproportionate number of studies of STEM education have focused singularly on comparative studies with other racial/ethnic populations, obscuring individual differences in student characteristics and experiences. Further, the study of race and gender processes often occur in isolation of one another, with gender studies excluding issues of race and/or populations of color and studies focused on race processes in education giving little explicit attention to ways that race processes are embedded in gender. By examining diverse student samples from different campus contexts, project investigators addressed important questions about the nature of academic development among African American students in ways that can support the efforts of researchers and institutions to encourage successful academic development in STEM and in higher education more generally.

Specific implications for institutional practice include the need to develop or improve programming that seeks to increase women’s presence in STEM by taking into account issues of race and better integrating supports for women of color. Similarly, for efforts intended to enhance racial/ethnic minority students’ participation in STEM, project findings can help inform how issues of gender relevant to both women and men might be included in programs and practice. Finally, the findings showing complementary links between students’ social and cultural identities and their academic identity, engagement, and persistence suggest that institutional policy and practices should consider ways to better affirm, acknowledge, and engage students’ personal and cultural identities in classroom and other learning contexts.

The project’s intellectual merit is in its potential to inform educational efforts to improve and support the development of students from underrepresented backgrounds in higher education. These students are even more underrepresented in STEM. The project also begins to address methodological and conceptual limitations in extant research literature about academic and social/psychological mechanisms that explain why talented and promising African American students access and persist in STEM at lower rates than other groups. In addition, the research focus on variation among ethnic minority students in risk and success is transformative in nature in that it provides an innovative, interdisciplinary and non-deficit approach to studying miniroty student identity development in STEM and the roles of race, gender, and social class. Finally, the project has had broader impact in research communities and the institutions in which the project was situated. These broader impacts occurred through training of signi?cant numbers of undergraduate and graduate students and postdoctoral fellows from racial and gender groups and other minority identities that have traditionally been underrepresented in science, and through our engagement efforts in our study institutions, e.g., partnering around applications of the research for programmatic and intervention purposes.
